Representing IPv6 Zone Identifiers in Address Literals and Uniform Representing IPv6 Zone Identifiers in Address Literals and Uniform
Resource Identifiers Resource Identifiers
draft-ietf-6man-rfc6874bis-05 draft-ietf-6man-rfc6874bis-06X
Abstract Abstract
This document describes how the zone identifier of an IPv6 scoped This document describes how the zone identifier of an IPv6 scoped
address, defined as <zone_id> in the IPv6 Scoped Address Architecture address, defined as <zone_id> in the IPv6 Scoped Address Architecture
(RFC 4007), can be represented in a literal IPv6 address and in a (RFC 4007), can be represented in a literal IPv6 address and in a
Uniform Resource Identifier that includes such a literal address. It Uniform Resource Identifier that includes such a literal address. It
updates the URI Generic Syntax and Internationalized Resource updates the URI Generic Syntax and Internationalized Resource
Identifier specifications (RFC 3986, RFC 3987) accordingly, and Identifier specifications (RFC 3986, RFC 3987) accordingly, and
obsoletes RFC 6874. obsoletes RFC 6874.

defined how a literal IPv6 address can be represented in the "host" defined how a literal IPv6 address can be represented in the "host"
part of a URI. Two months later, the IPv6 Scoped Address part of a URI. Later, the IPv6 Scoped Address Architecture
Architecture specification [RFC4007] extended the text representation specification [RFC4007] extended the text representation of limited-
of limited-scope IPv6 addresses such that a zone identifier may be scope IPv6 addresses such that a zone identifier may be concatenated
concatenated to a literal address, for purposes described in that to a literal address, for purposes described in that specification.
specification. Zone identifiers are especially useful in contexts in Zone identifiers are especially useful in contexts in which literal
which literal addresses are typically used, for example, during fault addresses are typically used, for example, during fault diagnosis,
diagnosis, when it may be essential to specify which interface is when it may be essential to specify which interface is used for
used for sending to a link-local address. It should be noted that sending to a link-local address. It should be noted that zone
zone identifiers have purely local meaning within the node in which identifiers have purely local meaning within the node in which they
they are defined, usually being the same as IPv6 interface names. are defined, usually being the same as IPv6 interface names. They
They are completely meaningless for any other node. Today, they are are completely meaningless for any other node. Today, they are
meaningful only when attached to link-local addresses, but it is meaningful only when attached to link-local addresses, but it is
possible that other uses might be defined in the future. possible that other uses might be defined in the future.
The IPv6 Scoped Address Architecture specification [RFC4007] does not The IPv6 Scoped Address Architecture specification does not specify
specify how zone identifiers are to be represented in URIs. how zone identifiers are to be represented in URIs. Practical
Practical experience has shown that this feature is useful or experience has shown that this feature is useful or necessary, in
necessary, in various use cases, including the following: various use cases, including the following:
1. A web browser may be used for simple debugging actions involving 1. A web browser may be used for simple debugging actions involving
link-local addresses on a host with more than one active link link-local addresses on a host with more than one active link
interface. interface. For example, the existence of a device may today be
checked via "ping fe80::1234%eth0" but not via
"https://[fe80::1234%eth0]".
2. A web browser must sometimes be used to configure or reconfigure 2. A web browser must sometimes be used to configure or reconfigure
a device which only has a link local address and whose only a device which only has a link-local address and whose only
configuration tool is a web server, again in a host with more configuration tool is a web server, again in a host with more
than one active link interface. than one active link interface. For example, a typical home
router may today be configured via "http://192.168.178.1" but not
via "http://[fe80::1%eth0]".
3. The Apple and open-source CUPS printing mechanism [CUPS] 3. The Apple and open-source CUPS printing mechanism [CUPS]
[OP-CUPS] uses an HTTP-based protocol [RFC3510][RFC7472] to [OP-CUPS] uses an HTTP-based protocol [RFC3510][RFC7472] to
establish link-local relationships, so requires the specification establish link-local relationships, so requires the specification
of the relevant interface. of the relevant interface.
4. The Microsoft Web Services for Devices (WSD) virtual printer port 4. The Microsoft Web Services for Devices (WSD) virtual printer port
mechanism can generate an IPv6 Link Local URL in which the zone mechanism can generate an IPv6 link-local URL such as
identifier is present and necessary, but is not recognized by any "http://[fe80::823b:f9ff:fe7b:d9dc%10]:80/WebServices/Device" in
current browser. which the zone identifier is present, but is not recognized by
any current browser.
For these use cases, it is highly desirable that a complete IPv6
link-local address can be cut and pasted from one context (such as
the output from a system command) to another (such as a browser
dialogue box). Since such addresses may include quite long
hexadecimal strings, any solution except cut-and-paste is highly
error prone.
The use cases listed above apply to relatively simple actions on end
systems, not to network infrastructure devices. The latter may have
large numbers of interfaces, which are commonly named for network
management purposes in styles such as "Ethernet1/0/1" or "ge-
0/0/0.0", reflecting the hardware structure and depending on the
manufacturer. The present specification does not intend to support
such names, which commonly involve upper case and non-alphanumeric
characters. Generally speaking they are handled by various network
management mechanisms and specialized commands, so there is no
requirement to support them in URIs.
As IPv6 deployment becomes widespread, the lack of a solution for As IPv6 deployment becomes widespread, the lack of a solution for
handling complete link local addresses in web browsers is becoming an handling complete link-local addresses in web browsers is becoming an
acute problem for increasing numbers of operational and support acute problem for increasing numbers of operational and support
personnel. It will become critical as IPv6-only networks, with no personnel. It will become critical as IPv6-only networks, with no
native IPv4 support, appear. This is the principal reason for native IPv4 support, appear. This is the principal reason for
documenting this requirement and its solution now. documenting this requirement and its solution now.
It should be noted that whereas some operating systems and network It should be noted that whereas some operating systems and network
APIs support a default zone identifier as described in [RFC4007], APIs support a default zone identifier as described in [RFC4007],
others do not, and for them an appropriate URI syntax is particularly others do not, and for them an appropriate URI syntax is particularly
important. important.

introducing two hexadecimal characters representing some percent- characters representing some percent-encoded octet as explained in
encoded octet [RFC3986]. Clearly, interpreting the "%" sign as Section 2.1 of [RFC3986]. Clearly, interpreting the "%" sign as
introducing a zone identifier is very convenient for users, although introducing a zone identifier is very convenient for users, although
it is not supported by the URI syntax in [RFC3986] or the it is not supported by the URI syntax in RFC 3986 or the
Internationalized Resource Identifier (IRI) syntax in [RFC3987]. Internationalized Resource Identifier (IRI) syntax in [RFC3987].
Therefore, this document updates RFC 3986 and RFC 3987 by adding Therefore, this document updates RFC 3986 and RFC 3987 by adding
syntax to allow a zone identifier to be included in a literal IPv6 syntax to allow a zone identifier to be included in a literal IPv6
address within a URI. address within a URI.

the presence of a percent ("%") character within an IPv6 address the presence of a percent ("%") character within an IPv6 address
literal. For this reason, it is backwards compatible to allow the literal. For this reason, it is backwards compatible to allow the
use of "%" within an IPv6 address literal as a delimiter only, such use of "%" within an IPv6 address literal as a delimiter only, such

literal, and is irrelevant to and exempt from the percent-encoding literal, and is irrelevant to and exempt from the percent-encoding
mechanism [RFC3986]. mechanism of RFC 3986.
A zone identifier MUST contain only ASCII characters classified as A zone identifier MUST contain only ASCII characters classified as
"unreserved" for use in URIs [RFC3986]. This excludes characters "unreserved" for use in URIs by RFC 3986. This excludes characters
such as "]" or even "%" that would complicate parsing. For the such as "/", "]" or even "%" that would complicate parsing. For the
avoidance of doubt, note that a zone identifier consisting of "25" or avoidance of doubt, note that a zone identifier consisting of "25" or
starting with "25" is valid and is used in some operating systems. A starting with "25" is valid and is used in some operating systems. A
parser MUST NOT apply percent decoding to the IPv6 address literal in parser MUST NOT apply percent decoding to the IPv6 address literal in
a URI, including cases such as http://[fe80::abcd%25] and a URI, including cases such as "http://[fe80::abcd%25]" and
http://[fe80::abcd%25xy]. "http://[fe80::abcd%25xy]".

identifiers that are not in the "unreserved" character set, they identifiers that are not in the "unreserved" character set,
cannot be used in a URI. identifiers including them cannot be used in a URI.

identifiers, identifiers including upper case letters cannot be used
in a URI.

The URI syntax specification [RFC3986] formally defines the IPv6 The URI syntax specification in RFC 3986 formally defines the IPv6
literal format in ABNF [RFC5234] by the following rule: literal format in ABNF [RFC5234] by the following rule:
IP-literal = "[" ( IPv6address / IPvFuture ) "]" IP-literal = "[" ( IPv6address / IPvFuture ) "]"
To provide support for a zone identifier, the existing syntax of To provide support for a zone identifier, the existing syntax of
IPv6address is retained, and a zone identifier may be added IPv6address is retained, and a zone identifier may be added
optionally to any literal address. This syntax allows flexibility optionally to any literal address. This syntax allows flexibility
for unknown future uses. The rule quoted above from [RFC3986] is for unknown future uses. The rule quoted above from RFC 3986 is
replaced by three rules: replaced by three rules:
IP-literal = "[" ( IPv6address / IPv6addrz / IPvFuture ) "]" IP-literal = "[" ( IPv6address / IPv6addrz / IPvFuture ) "]"
ZoneID = 1*( unreserved ) ZoneID = 1*( unreserved )
IPv6addrz = IPv6address "%" ZoneID IPv6addrz = IPv6address "%" ZoneID

RFC 3986 also states that the host subcomponent of a URI is case- RFC 3986 also states that the host subcomponent of a URI is case-
insensitive and is normalised to lower case. The mechanism described insensitive and is normalized to lower case. Section 6.2.2.1 of RFC
here will therefore fail for zone identifiers that contain upper case 3986 states unambiguously that "the scheme and host are case-
letters, since RFC 4007 implies case-sensitivity. insensitive and therefore should be normalized to lowercase". The
mechanism described here will therefore fail for zone identifiers
that contain upper case letters, since RFC 4007 implies case-
sensitivity. This specification therefore RECOMMENDS the use of
lower case letters only when assigning zone identifiers to
interfaces.

4. Scope and Deployment 4. Scope and Deployment
A URI (or IRI) using this format has no meaning outside the scope of A URI (or IRI) using this format has no meaning outside the scope of
the individual host that orginates it and of the specific layer 2 the individual host that originates it and of the specific layer 2
link concerned. It may in fact be delivered in an HTTP message to a link concerned. It may in fact be delivered in an HTTP message to a
server that does not support this format and which will reject the server that does not support this format and which will reject the
message as invalid. For the diagnostic use cases concerned, this is message as invalid. For the diagnostic use cases concerned, this is
of no importance: an HTTP error response will serve the diagnostic of no importance: an HTTP error response will serve the diagnostic
purpose of establishing that the link and remote host are purpose of establishing that the link and remote host are
operational. The other use cases shown above are only meaningful if operational. The other use cases shown above are only meaningful if
the remote host also accepts this format; otherwise they will fail the remote host also accepts this format; otherwise they will fail
with an HTTP error response. As a result, this format can be with an HTTP error response. As a result, this format can be
deployed progressively as required, with no wider consequences. deployed progressively as required, with no wider consequences.

5. URI Parsers 5. URI Parsers
This section discusses how URI (or IRI) parsers, such as those This section discusses how URI (or IRI) parsers, such as those
embedded in web browsers, might handle this syntax extension. embedded in web browsers, might handle this syntax extension.
In practice, although parsers respect the established syntax, they In practice, although parsers respect the established syntax, many
are coded pragmatically rather than being formally syntax-driven. are coded pragmatically rather than being formally syntax-driven.
Typically, IP address literals are handled by an explicit code path. Typically, IP address literals are handled by an explicit code path.
Parsers have been inconsistent in providing for zone identifiers. Parsers have been inconsistent in providing for zone identifiers.
Most have no support, but there have been examples of ad hoc support. Most have no support, but there have been examples of ad hoc support.
For example, some versions of Firefox allowed the use of a zone For example, some versions of Firefox allowed the use of a zone
identifier preceded by a bare "%" character, but this feature was identifier preceded by a bare "%" character, but this feature was
removed for consistency with established syntax [RFC3986]. As removed for consistency with the established syntax of RFC 3986. As
another example, some versions of Internet Explorer allowed use of a another example, some versions of Internet Explorer allowed use of a
zone identifier preceded by a "%" character encoded as "%25", still zone identifier preceded by a "%" character encoded as "%25", still
beyond the syntax allowed by the established rules [RFC3986]. This beyond the syntax allowed by the established rules. This syntax
syntax extension is in fact used internally in the Windows operating extension is in fact used internally in the Windows operating system
system and some of its APIs. and some of its APIs.
URI parsers SHOULD accept a zone identifier according to the syntax URI parsers SHOULD accept a zone identifier according to the syntax
defined in Section 3. An IPv6 address literal never contains defined in Section 3, rather than treating the URI as invalid as they
percent-encodings. In terms of Section 2.4 of [RFC3986], the "%" do today. An IPv6 address literal never contains percent-encodings.
character preceding a zone identifier is acting as a delimiter, not In terms of Section 2.4 of [RFC3986], the "%" character preceding a
as data. Any code handling percent-encoding or percent-decoding must zone identifier is acting as a delimiter, not as data. Any code
be aware of this. handling percent-encoding or percent-decoding must be aware of this.
As noted above, a zone identifier included in a URI has no meaning As noted above, a zone identifier included in a URI has no meaning
outside the originating HTTP client node. However, in some use outside the originating HTTP client node. However, in some use
cases, such as CUPS, the host address embedded in the URI will be cases, such as CUPS, the host address embedded in the URI will be
reflected back to the client, using exactly the representation of the reflected back to the client, using exactly the representation of the
zone identifier that the client sent. zone identifier that the client sent.

Such visibility of the zone identifier to a server is at most a minor Such visibility of the zone identifier to a server is at most a minor
security concern, since the information revealed is of local security concern, since the information revealed is of local
significance only and will be exploitable only if both the client significance only and will be exploitable only if both the client

Unfortunately there is no formal limit on the length of the zone Unfortunately there is no formal limit on the length of the zone
identifier string [RFC4007]. An implementation SHOULD apply a identifier string in RFC 4007. An implementation SHOULD apply a
reasonable length limit when generating a URI, for example 64 ASCII reasonable length limit when generating a URI, in order to minimize
characters, in order to minimize the risk of a buffer overrun. the risk of a buffer overrun. For example, a limit to 16 ASCII
characters would correspond to the existing limit on Linux interface
names.
An implementation SHOULD NOT include ASCII NULL characters in a zone
identifier string as this could cause inconsistencies in subsequent
string processing.

In the case that a zone identifier contains the hexadecimal MAC
address of a network interface, it will be revealed to the HTTP
recipient and to any observer on the link. Since the MAC address
will also be visible in the underlying layer 2 frame, this is not a
new exposure. Nevertheless, this method of naming interfaces might
be considered to be a privacy issue.

outdated Modified EUI format [RFC4291] for its link-local address, outdated Modified EUI format [RFC4291] for its link-local address,
the search space for an attacker is very significantly reduced, as the search space for an attacker is very significantly reduced, as
discussed in Section 4.1.1.1 of [RFC7707]. The resultant discussed in Section 4.1.1.1 of [RFC7707]. The resultant
recommendations of [RFC8064] apply to all nodes, including routers, recommendations of [RFC8064] apply to all nodes, including routers,
since they ensure that the search space for an attacker is of size since they ensure that the search space for an attacker is of size
2**64, which is impracticably large. 2**64, which is impracticably large.

Appendix B. Change log Appendix B. Change log
This section is to be removed before publishing as an RFC. This section is to be removed before publishing as an RFC.
* draft-ietf-6man-rfc6874bis-06, 2023-03-xx:
- Noted potential exposure of MAC addresses in zone IDs.
- Expanded detail on lower-case normalization.
- Added specific use case examples.
- Clearly stated cut-and-paste requirement.
- Mentioned .local as another case of locally significant URIs.
- Indicated that network infrastructure devices are out of scope.
- Other IESG review nits.
